content:
If you are running Windows, please, as a diagnostic, start the Operating System in Safe Mode with Networking privileges and see if the problem persists.

If the problem is resolved, there is likely to be a conflict between TB and another piece of software. By launching background software one by one, it should be seen what the conflict is with.

Most of these issues seem to be associated with Third Party anti-virus software so turning that on first if you use it would be the way to go.

content:
A folder named Spam or Bulk is created by the mail provider, to store junk mail before TB accesses the account. If Junk controls are activated in TB, a Junk folder is created - independent of the Spam filtering.

Some providers have an option in webmail settings to move mail from Spam to the Inbox with something like [SPAM] added to the Subject. You can also have the Spam folder checked when getting new mail by checking the box in folder Properties (right-click menu).

creator: andrepatry

content:
andrepatry said
I created a 2nd account years ago and it has worked since then. Now when I create a third account, it works well but when I disconnect I loose the account and have to recreate it again. How come?

In every instance of that sort of issue the cause has been Thunderbird being unable to write the updated prefs.js file to disk when it is closed. In Windows this is most usually caused by software blocking Thunderbird (read usually antivirus) but as this is a contention issue it can have many causes> Some examples are the profile being stored on a remote drive or some sort of home brew cloud synchronization that does not really work, only looks like it, or in extreme cases the disk has errors and the operating system can not overwrite the existing file. On non windows system antivirus is less of an issue, but on those folk do things like run Thunderbird in a temp folder and it is deleted on every startup.

So first check in the troubleshooting information on the help menu that your newly added account is truly no longer in the saved settings (look at "Mail and News accounts") then start looking for the cause of the contention.

The exception to the above is adding a POP mail account with the use of the global inbox which will not see the account appear in the folder list as mail will go to local folders.

content:
What do you see in this location?

  • In Account Settings
  • Select 'Server Settings' for the third account which keeps disappearing.
  • Bottom right - 'Local directory'
  • Make window wide enough to show the full details
  • Post image showing what it says.

re :Strangely, when I click on the Local File link in TB

You need to be more specific about what you are clicking on. Do you mean you did this:

  • In Thunderbird
  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - half way - 'Profile Folder' - click on 'Open Folder' button

If you use that method does it open on this ?

  • C:\Users\test\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\rm7ha0fz.default-release


re :I get a list of all 6 profiles including my two original ones.

The image is showing mail accounts not profiles. All of them are in the same profile but image does no show the full directory, so unable to be sure where it is.

Check you accessing the correct location by using this method:

  • Exit Thunderbird now.
  • In windows search type : %Appdata% - see image as guide
  • Select : %Appdata% file folder
  • Select : 'Roaming' folder
  • Select : 'Thunderbird' folder
  • Select 'Profiles' folder to see profile name folder
  • If you see rm7ha0fz.default-release folder select it to see contents

Look for 'prefs.js' file.

  • Right click on the 'prefs.js' file and select 'Properties'
  • On 'General' tab at bottom is 'Attributes'
  • Is the 'Read only' checkbox selected ?
  • If yes, then uncheck it.
  • Click on 'Apply'
  • click ion 'OK'

Please report on what you discovered.

How many of those 'prefs.js' files do you see? Do you see same file but with an added number eg: 'prefs-1.js ? If you see a few of them - what's the biggest number you see eg: 'prefs-110.js' ?

What Anti-Virus are you using ? Please make sure Anti-Virus in not allowed to scan anything in the Thunderbird profile folder nor fix anything in profile folder. If you have any Cleanup software like CCleaner or Wisecleaner or even some Anti-Virus products offer to clean up temp files, session files etc. Please do not allow any of these products to have access to anything in the Thunderbird profile folder. You do not want anything being auto removed or preventing any file updates when you exit Thunderbird. Please report back on what Cleanup software youhave been using and confirm you stopped/make exceptions to stop those programs from accessing the Thunderbird profile folder or it's contents. eg: C:\Users\test\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird

content:
There is a discrepancy on profile location.

When you post an image it needs to contain vital information on where you are looking and actual contents of the file - not the result of a search.

Initially you said you had located profile here: C:\Users\test\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\rm7ha0fz.default-release But then mention: C:\Users\andre\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\<unknown profile name>

They are two entirely different computer user accounts. Q: When you boot up computer - what User Account do you use/logon to 'test' or 'andre' ?

You posted an image showing actual contents of a profile which had 'prefs-1.js', 'prefs-2.js', 'prefs-3.js', 'prefs-4.js' - but it does not show a 'prefs.js' nor does it show the directory so we know what location you are viewing.

Thunderbird does not operate without a 'prefs.js'. So it sounds like one profile is being used to store profile data but it's not pointing to that location. What profile is storing the accounts and what profile you apparently use are not one and the same.

Initially, you downloaded and installed Thunderbird from official website and it put profile in default location.

Q: Did you reinstall Thunderbird by getting it from the Windows App Store ?

Post an image of both of the following directory which shows all the 'prefs' in both of these lcoations:

  • C:\Users\test\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\rm7ha0fz.default-release
  • C:\Users\andre\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\<unknown profile name>

content:
"Your draft message was not copied to your drafts folder (Drafts) due to network or file access errors."

This isn't a certificate error. Why do you think your email provider has an invalid certificate?

Annoyingly, it also seems to prevent me saving the message I just wrote into the Drafts folder.

As a workaround you can select the Drafts folder underneath the Local Folders account as Drafts folder for your IMAP account. Check your Account Settings - Copies & Folders.
creator: christ1

content:
Two separate issues.

An invalid certificate was preventing Thunderbird from connecting to SMTP & IMAP.

Separately, I cannot save to the mailbox Drafts folder any time I can't connect to the server. Why not? Shouldn't the message get saved to the local replica of the Drafts folder, & sync to the server next time there is a connection? Just the same as other synced folders?
creator: mailreceipter

content:
An invalid certificate was preventing Thunderbird from connecting to SMTP & IMAP.

Was? So the problem is gone now? If not, please post a screenshot of the error.

Shouldn't the message get saved to the local replica of the Drafts folder, & sync to the server next time there is a connection?

It's the other way round. The message is uploaded to the server, and then synced with the local email client.
creator: christ1

content:
Select the messages in the list, then Ctrl+S (File/Save As...) to save them as eml files to an external directory.

Folders can also be saved or exported as mbox files (one mbox per folder), but saving as eml is simpler.

I have tried to import messages with thunderbird but there are no messages or subfolders in the Apple mail folder. Folders such as sent mail or spam are not visible either. If the account was added as IMAP, right-click the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe..., and check the boxes for the missing folders. If it's a POP setup, only the Inbox is downloaded, not Spam or other folders visible in webmail. If the account was POP in Mail, copying the subfolders to TB is a bit more involved.

content:
Perhaps you are overthinking this. Understandable coming from the world of pop, but not applicable to imap - the imap defaults are decent and sane about keeping messages. The only thing I change is not immediately marking messages as read.

To lead with three items: 1. If you are reading about other losing messages, these are likely exceptional cases, please provide links. Or old - old being from older than 1 year, or even 3 months 2. Significant improvements have been made even in the last few months with version 128. 3. Some users conflate messages lost with situations where messages still exist but are not displaying.

Now, what have you been seeing with version 128.
creator: wsmwk

Regarding not being able to uncheck "Automatically mark messages as read"...

creator: gazjampat

content:
gazjampat said
This account has been IMAP for about 5 years and I have never had this problem before. Is this something that is relatively new? I have not used TB in about 1 year.

No, it's not new. It's how all Imap accounts work no matter what third party email client you use. All Imap accounts can only display whatever is on server. That is their purpose, emails are stored on server and Imap accounts gets access to server and all folders on the server. Imap accounts synchronise with server. Because all Imap accounts are designed to only display whatever is on server, you should never consider anything to be an independent copy on your computer. The benefit of Imap accounts means you can see identical emails via browser accessing webmail account and any other including multiple devices that use imap eg: Desktop, Laptop, phone that use imap to access emails.

Pop accounts are different. Pop accounts can only access the server Inbox and download emails from that folder. They cannot access any other folder on server. Pop accounts store emails on your computer. They do not synchronise with server. Deleting emails off server has no effect on emails fully downloaded into a Pop mail account. Pop accounts are considered an independent copy on your computer. Pop accounts are best used when you only access via one computer.

If you use Imap and need to keep a separate copy of emails so originals can be deleted off server, then fully download them and then get 'Copy' into a suitable fiolder in 'Local Folders' account. Emails stored in 'Local Folders' account are an independent copy and do not synchronise with server. Once you have a good copy you can remove emails off the server.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Dear Toad Hall, Thanks for the detailed explanation. Now I understand the difference and how to use IMAP correctly.

creator: davidsk

content:
Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

content:
@frisée

There is no error message. TB only requires a new password when accessing the accounts and does not use the passwords who are already saved.

This happens almost every time when I restart TB. When TB has been running for a while, it knows all the passwords.

I assume that if TB has a bad connection at startup, it can't connect to the server and therefore assumes the password is wrong... so TB requires new passwords. TB then probably deletes the old passwords. This only happens for the accounts that are loaded first.

I just need to know the name of the file in which TB stores the passwords ... then I can make a BAT job that saves this file before starting TB. I can then use this backup if TB breaks the password file at startup.

This is a bug who exists also if Windows connect to a W-LAN who ask for a password. When the W-LAN do not receive the correct passwort and state that the password is ok, then the user must send the passwort at new ... and then the old password was deleted on the client side. When the client send a wrong or broken password he get the message wrong password and then he ask for a new password.

Thanks, Jo

content:
Never done this myself, I think you should be fine as long as you

1. do what's necessary for windows 11 user to access the windows 10 file system 2. give the windows 11 user read+write access to the c:\users\<win10-user>\APPDATA\ roaming\thunderbird path and subdirectories 3. give the windows 11 user read+write access to the c:\users\<win10user>\APPDATA\ local\thunderbird path and subdirectories 4. use the same Thunderbird version, safest is use only the Thunderbird installed via windows 10 5. specify absolute paths in profiles.ini (not relative) to point to the profile 6. on both systems start Thunderbird using what's installed on win10 using full path to the profile on windows 10 

 c:\program files (x86)\Thunderbird\thunderbird.exe -profile c:\users\<win10user>\APPDATA\ roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<full-profile-foldername>

(make sure you copy that full line above)

You might get away with installing thunderbird installed on both systems and running their own executable? Maybe??

content: Thunderbird does not support dynamic back scroll, which means most old messages from previous sessions will not be shown. Only your unread messages are shown on initial connection, and all messages that are sent to rooms later on. However, sometimes it is ambiguous which messages are still unread, and this can cause some old messages to be shown.

content:
If you are running Windows, please, as a diagnostic, start the Operating System in Safe Mode with Networking privileges and see if the problem persists.

If the problem is resolved, there is likely to be a conflict between TB and another piece of software. By launching background software one by one, it should be seen what the conflict is with.

Most of these issues seem to be associated with Third Party anti-virus software so turning that on first if you use it would be the way to go.
